awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:Investigation of Material Removal in Impact Machining by Loose Abrasives
awd_abstract_narration:
Existing nanomachining processes that rely on lithographic and energy beam based methods often need cleanroom environments and huge capital investments. Their shortcomings include limited choice of work materials, chemical hazards, and thermally induced defects on machined surfaces. This award supports a study of material removal in brittle materials by the impact of nano diamond particles. Research results can lead to a low cost alternative for nanomachining at room temperature without the shortcomings of existing nanomachining processes. The new process can improve the nanomachinability of a wide variety of both conductive and nonconductive materials, and may have applications in biomedical, electronic, automotive, energy, and metal working industries. Potential applications in these industries include nanostructured scaffolds for artificial tissue engineering, nanostructured switches and wireless transmitters, ultra-low friction layers for thermal barrier coatings, and nanostructured proton exchange membranes for fuel cells. 
 
The experimental platform for the new process is an atomic force microscope where workpiece is vibrated at the frequency of 20-160 kHz. Machining is achieved by the impact of loose nano diamond particles in liquid medium. The research objective is to understand effects of kinetic energy on material removal mechanism (plastic deformation or brittle fracture). The level of kinetic energy is determined by machining conditions (primarily diamond particle size and vibration frequency). The research plan consists of computer simulations and experimental studies. Extended finite element methods will be used to simulate the machining process. In these models, to mimic the impact given by the diamond particle on the workpiece at different kinetic energy levels, the workpiece is fixed and the diamond particle is treated as a vibrating rigid body (at the frequency of 20-160 kHz). Drucker-Prager constitutive law will be employed to describe the behavior of brittle materials. Finite element models will be validated by comparing model predictions with experimental results. Machining experiments using graphene, silicon, and glass samples will be performed at different levels of kinetic energy by varying the mean size of diamond particles (5, 10, 15 nm) and vibrating the workpiece at different frequencies in the range of 20-160 kHz. Machined surfaces will be examined using electron microscopy, and optical microscope to determine if the material removal is done by plastic deformation or brittle fracture.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to investigate the novel nanomachining process, Vibration Assisted Nano Impact machining by Loose Abrasives (VANILA) process, wherein brittle materials are removed through the impact of nanoabrasives. In VANILA process, the experimental platform is an atomic force microscope (AFM) where the AFM tip is vibrated at the frequency of 20-160 kHz. Machining is achieved by the impact of loose nano diamond particles in a liquid medium located between AFM vibrating tip and the brittle workpiece to be machined. The research objective is to understand effects of kinetic energy on the material removal mechanism (plastic deformation or brittle fracture). To be more specific, the effects of the impact speed, which is associated with vibration frequency of the AFM tip, impact angle, friction coefficient between nanoparticles and the workpiece, and operating temperature are investigated in this research.

This research shows that the commercial Finite Element Method (FEM) software package ABAQUS can be used to simulate this novel nanomachining process to investigate the material removal mechanisms under different levels of kinetic energy. The Drucker-Prager constitutive law is employed to describe the behavior of the brittle workpiece material (silicon). The nanoscale FEM models built using ABAQUS has been successfully validated by comparing with analytical results.

Base on the experimental results, there are no random cracks on the top of the silicon workpiece after VANILA machining. Therefore, it is hypothesized that the ductile regime machining (DRM) of brittle material occurs during VANILA machining process, which can be achieved when the hydrostatic pressure during loading reaches the hardness value of the brittle workpiece materials. The simulation results show that the highest hydrostatic pressure of silicon during VANILA machining process is around 25.3 GPa, which is much higher than silicon?s hardness (14 GPa). Hence, ductile damage model is suitable to be applied for silicon in VANILA.

Phase transformation for silicon in VANILA is also investigated using ABAQUS. During VANILA nanomachining, the contact area of silicon workpiece experiences different values of hydrostatic pressure induced by the impact of diamond abrasives. The silicon phase transformation occurs when the impact-induced hydrostatic pressure in contact area changes. Impact speed is found to have the most dominating effect on the phase transformation process, followed by impact angle and friction coefficient. The research results also show that operating temperature has substantial influence on the material removal volume. The two operating temperatures (400 degree C and 600 degree C) are promising operating temperatures. The research results also show that the number of impact hits has substantial influence on material removal volume of the silicon workpiece. The research results obtained from this project shows that the FEM is not only feasible to model nanoscale impact machining, but also promising to model other nanoscale mechanical processes.

In addition, the effects of the operating parameters (impact speed, impact angle, and operating temperature) on the depth and width of generated nanocavities along with the impact-induced phase transformation in the VANILA process are investigated using Molecular Dynamics Simulation (LAMMPS). The simulation results show that the operating parameters have substantial influence on the depth and width of the generated nanocavities and phase transformation is clearly observed.

Research results provide insight to the material removal mechanisms, the range of machinable feature sizes, the effect of machining parameters on the productivity of the machined features, and phase transformation during VANILA. VANILA turns out to be a revolutionary nanomanufacturing approach as it does not require cleanroom or huge capital investment required for most of the existing nanomanufacturing technologies and will have transformative effect of the nanomachinability of a wide variety of both conductive and nonconductive materials. VANILA may have applications in biomedical, electronic, automotive, energy, and metal working industries. Knowledge gained from this project is invaluable for the innovation and advancement of hybrid nanomachining processes such as nanoscale abrasive water jet machining, where the constituent material removal mechanism involves machining by loose nano abrasives. Research results may serve as prelude to abrasive based picofinishing technology. A PhD student and two female undergraduate students have been trained in this project. The PI has included research results obtained from this project as a module in a graduate course (Advanced Manufacturing processes) he teaches at Saint Louis University. The results of this research have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journals, presentations at international conferences (ASME MSEC, NAMRC, and ASME IMECE), and reports to NSF. In addition, published/accepted publications have been made available in the PI's website. This experience will be further used to nurture training and learning among women and underrepresented minorities, and build up partnership with area school community.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2019
Modified by: Jianfeng J Ma
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project aims to investigate the novel nanomachining process, Vibration Assisted Nano Impact machining by Loose Abrasives (VANILA) process, wherein brittle materials are removed through the impact of nanoabrasives. VANILA may have applications in biomedical, electronic, automotive, energy, and metal working industries. Knowledge gained from this project is invaluable for the innovation and advancement of hybrid nanomachining processes such as nanoscale abrasive water jet machining, where the constituent material removal mechanism involves machining by loose nano abrasives. Research results may serve as prelude to abrasive based picofinishing technology. A PhD student and two female undergraduate students have been trained in this project. The PI has included research results obtained from this project as a module in a graduate course (Advanced Manufacturing processes) he teaches at Saint Louis University. The results of this research have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journals, presentations at international conferences (ASME MSEC, NAMRC, and ASME IMECE), and reports to NSF. In addition, published/accepted publications have been made available in the PI's website. This experience will be further used to nurture training and learning among women and underrepresented minorities, and build up partnership with area school community.
